dataIdInfo.idPurp: This data set of wildland fire perimeter (fire scar) data is intended for scientific purposes and planning by communities, natural resource managers, and emergency response agencies. This is not, however, the case for commercial purposes. Users are prohibited from any commercial, non-free resale, or redistribution without explicit written permission from the NREM Wildland Fire Program at the University of Hawaii at Manoa (www.nrem-fire.org; trauerni@hawaii.edu). We kindly ask any users to cite the UH Manoa NREM Fire Perimeter Data Set as the source used in the creation of any reports, publications, new data sets, derived products, or services resulting from the use of this data set.
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
This data set is comprised of vector data (polygons) of wildland fire perimeters for Hawaii state from 1999 to present for fires greater than or equal to 50 acres (20 hectares). It has been compiled and derived primarily from satellite imagery and includes a combination of data sources and original fire mapping by the University of Hawaii at Manoa Wildland Fire Program in the Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Management. This is considered a 'living' data set and will be updated, based on availability of continued funding, on an annual basis. No fire history is complete, and it is likely that fires are missing from this data set. If you are aware of missing incidents, please contact the lead author of this data set, Clay Trauernicht (trauerni@hawaii.edu).

The attribute field YYYYMMDD is the day the fire was 'discovered', reported and/or responded to (ie, YEAR, MONTH, DAY). "Sat_sz_ac" is the fire size, in acres, determined from the sattelite imagery (does not take into account variation in topography). "Inc_name" refers to fire names, if available. "Locale" is the general location of the fire, if described in the original report. The field "Source" refers to original data source for actual fire perimeters and includes the following categories: Hawaii Wildfire Management Organization (www.hawaiiwildfire.org) is a non-profit on Hawaii Island who has been compiling and mapping fires primarily in the N Kona-S Kohala region of Hawaii Island; National Park Service records are derived from the Hawaii Volcanoes National Park Fire Atlas for fires mapped within the park boundary; USGS_MTBS_perimeters_2002_2011 refers to an effort by the US Geological Survey's Monitoring Trends in Burn Severity program to map Hawaii State fires from LANDSAT imagery from 2002-2011; The Oahu Army Natural Resource Program refers to fires mapped primarily on Oahu by the DoD funded conservation program; UH_NREM_Fire_Satellite refers to fires mapped directly by the University of Hawaii Wildland Fire Program using landsat and/or sentinel-2 satellite imagery. "AgencyID", if available, is the original incident number as reported by the responding agency. The attribute field "UH_ID" refers to an internal system linking fire records back to point-based ignition data, enabling determination of the original agency records (point-based) with which the incident was located. The field "kmlname" refers to the filename of the kml files that stored for each fire as part of the satellite mapping data flow, and compiled as individual features in this shapefile.
dataIdInfo.idCredit: This effort was led by Clay Trauernicht (trauerni@hawaii.edu) in the Department of Natural Resources and Environmental Management in the College of Tropical Agriculture and Human Resources at the University of Hawaii at Manoa. The agencies and organizations outlined in the Description made this effort possible by sharing data. Madison Miyamura contributed to mapping fires as a technician. Thanks to the Hawaii Division of Forestry and Wildlife and the US Geological Survey for funding support as part of projects for developing a geospatial database for fire reporting and a statewide analysis of fire risk for Hawaii.

searchKeys.keyword: fire; fire scars; Hawaii; wildfire; fire perimeters; fire history

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.
